trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since 2018 with hundreds of successful missions including multiple lunar CLPS missions

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications: 549,054 kg / 1,207,920 lbs

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Corrected from $69.85M to $67M per multiple credible sources (SpaceNews, Space.com). SpaceX raised price from $62M to $67M in 2022 due to inflation

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Could not find. Checked SpaceX.com, SpaceNews, no public data on typical lead times for Falcon 9

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications: 22,800 kg / 50,265 lbs to LEO

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications: 8,300 kg / 18,300 lbs to GTO

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Not published by SpaceX. Checked SpaceX.com, NASA documents, academic sources. One forum post suggests ~1,973 kg but no authoritative source found. Actual lunar missions (e.g., IM-1 at 1,908 kg) suggest capacity in 1,900-2,000 kg range

items.notes: Most frequently launched rocket globally. Proven lunar mission capability with multiple successful CLPS missions. Reusable first stage.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since Feb 2018 with 11+ successful missions including Psyche (Oct 2023), USSF missions, and ViaSat-3

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications: 1,420,788 kg / 3,125,735 lbs

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Confirmed $97M list price for reusable configuration per SpaceNews. Price increased from $90M to $97M in 2022

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Checked SpaceX.com, SpaceNews, no public data on typical lead times for Falcon Heavy

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications: 63,800 kg / 140,660 lbs to LEO

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications: 26,700 kg / 58,860 lbs to GTO

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from SpaceX official specifications as 'Payload to Mars': 16,800 kg / 37,040 lbs. Mars trajectory similar to TLI energy requirements

items.notes: Heavy-lift variant using 3 Falcon 9 cores. Awarded NASA Gateway Dragon XL lunar resupply contract. Partially reusable with center core and side boosters.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since Jan 2024. Three successful missions: Cert-1 (Peregrine, Jan 2024), Cert-2 (Oct 2024), USSF-106 (Aug 2025). Certified by Space Force for NSSL missions March 2025

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: 546,700 kg / 1.2 million lbs total mass

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Estimated $110-120M per launch. Space Force contract: $1.3B for 11 launches averaging $118M. Varies by configuration (0-6 SRBs)

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Checked ULA official site and industry sources, no public data on procurement lead times

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ULA official specifications: 27,200 kg to LEO-Reference orbit (6 SRB configuration)

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ULA official specifications: 15,300 kg to GTO (Upgrade configuration with 6 SRBs)

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ULA official specifications: 2,300 kg to TLI (0 SRB configuration). Up to 12,100 kg with Upgrade configuration

items.notes: Modular design with 0, 2, 4, or 6 solid rocket boosters. Two BE-4 engines (main stage) and two RL10C engines (upper stage). Launched Peregrine lunar lander Jan 2024.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since Jan 2025. Two successful missions: NG-1 (Blue Ring, Jan 16 2025), NG-2 (ESCAPADE, Nov 13 2025). Successfully landed reusable booster

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: over 1,000 tons (1,000,000 kg) mass at liftoff

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Corrected from null to $68M. Not officially announced by Blue Origin, but estimated $60-90M range by industry sources. Arianespace estimates $68M

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Blue Origin official site and industry sources, no public data on procurement lead times

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from Blue Origin official specifications: 45,000 kg / 99,000 lbs to LEO

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 13,600 kg to 13,000 kg per Blue Origin official specifications: 13,000 kg / 29,000 lbs to GTO

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 7,000 kg to the Moon from multiple sources. Blue Origin official site does not list TLI capacity specifically

items.notes: 7 meter diameter, 98m tall. Seven BE-4 engines (1st stage), two BE-3U engines (2nd stage). Reusable first stage. Successfully launched Jan 2025 (Blue Ring), Nov 2025 (ESCAPADE).

trl.verification_notes: Announced Nov 20, 2025. No operational timeline provided. In development phase, not yet built or tested. TRL 6 appropriate for system in design/development phase

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Blue Origin site, SpaceNews, Aviation Week, Space.com - no mass specifications found

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. No official pricing announced. Checked Blue Origin site, SpaceNews, industry sources

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable - vehicle not yet operational. No timeline for service entry announced

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 77,000 kg to 70,000 kg per SpaceNews quoting Blue Origin announcement: 'more than 70 metric tons into low Earth orbit'

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 15,000 kg to 14,000 kg per Weekly Spaceman: 'more than 14 metric tons to direct GEO'

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 22,000 kg to 20,000 kg per SpaceNews: 'more than 20 metric tons on a translunar injection trajectory'

items.notes: Upgraded version with 9 BE-4 engines (1st stage), 4 BE-3U engines (2nd stage), 8.7m fairing. Announced Nov 2025 for development. No operational timeline provided.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since July 9, 2024 with maiden flight VA262. Multiple operational flights in 2024-2025

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ArianeGroup official specifications: 530 metric tons at liftoff

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Corrected from $85M to $77M per Motley Fool. Note: This is list price; actual cost with subsidies ~$115M

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Arianespace and ArianeGroup sites, no public data on procurement lead times

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 10,350 kg to 10,000 kg per ArianeGroup official specifications

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 5,000 kg to 4,500 kg per ArianeGroup official specifications: '4,500 kg to geostationary transfer orbit (GTO)'

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Not published by ArianeGroup or Arianespace. Checked official sites, ESA, no TLI capacity found

items.notes: Two P120C solid rocket boosters. Vulcain 2.1 main engine (1st stage), Vinci engine (2nd stage). Smaller variant of Ariane 6 family.

trl.verification_notes: TRL 8 - Not yet flown. First flight (VA267) delayed to 2026. Hardware being prepared at launch site. Per Arianespace CEO: 'at the very end of development phase'

mass_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 860,000 kg to 850,000 kg per ArianeGroup official specifications: 850 metric tons

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Corrected from $130M to $126M per Motley Fool. Note: This is list price; actual cost with subsidies higher

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Not yet operational. Checked Arianespace and ArianeGroup sites, no public data on procurement lead times

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 21,500 kg to 20,000 kg per ArianeGroup official specifications: '20,000 kg to LEO'

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ArianeGroup official specifications: 11,500 kg to GTO

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Not published by ArianeGroup or Arianespace. Checked official sites, ESA, no TLI capacity found

items.notes: Four P120C solid rocket boosters. Vulcain 2.1 main engine (1st stage), Vinci engine (2nd stage). More powerful variant. Future Block 3 upgrade planned for enhanced lunar capability.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since February 2024. First successful flight Feb 17, 2024. Multiple operational flights in 2024-2025 with 5 successes out of 6 missions

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: 574 metric tons (574,000 kg) total mass

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: ~$50M per launch. JAXA designed H3 to cost approximately $33M but expected price ~$50M

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Checked JAXA and MHI sites, no public data on procurement lead times

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: 16,000 kg to LEO for H3-24W (wide fairing) variant

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: 8,800 kg to GTO (∆V=1830 m/s)

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from multiple sources: 'more than 6,000 kg to lunar transfer orbit'

items.notes: Most powerful H3 variant. Two LE-9 engines (1st stage), LE-5B-3 engine (2nd stage), four SRB-3 solid boosters. Used for LUPEX lunar mission. 63m tall, 5.2m diameter.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since July 2019. First operational flight July 22, 2019 (Chandrayaan-2). 8 successful launches out of 8 attempts (100% success rate)

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ISRO official specifications: 640 tonnes lift-off mass

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. Production cost ~₹434 crore ($52M) per rocket, but commercial pricing by NewSpace India not publicly disclosed. Checked ISRO and NewSpace India sites

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Checked ISRO and NewSpace India sites, no public data on procurement lead times

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 10,000 kg to 8,000 kg per ISRO official specifications: 8,000 kg to LEO (600 km altitude)

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from ISRO official specifications: 4,000 kg to GTO

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Not published by ISRO. Chandrayaan-3 (3,900 kg) was launched to GTO, then performed its own TLI. No direct TLI capacity specified

items.notes: India's most powerful launch vehicle. Three-stage: S200 solid boosters, L110 liquid stage, C25 cryogenic upper stage. Launched Chandrayaan-2 and Chandrayaan-3. Commercially available via NewSpace India Limited. 43.5m tall.

trl.verification_notes: TRL 6 - In development. All major hardware built and in testing. First launch delayed to Q1 2026 or later per CEO Nov 2025

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Original JSON had 480,000 kg but this is not found in any authoritative sources. Checked Rocket Lab official site, Wikipedia, industry sources

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - launch vehicles do not have continuous power ratings like spacecraft

cost_usd.verification_notes: Added from null. Per Rocket Lab CFO: $50-55M per launch. Targeting to challenge SpaceX Falcon 9 pricing

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable - vehicle not yet operational. First launch expected Q1 2026 or later

payload_leo_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from Rocket Lab official site: 13,000 kg to LEO (with downrange booster landing)

payload_gto_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Rocket Lab official site, no GTO capacity specified

payload_tli_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Rocket Lab official site, no TLI capacity specified

items.notes: In development. 43m tall (141 ft). Nine Archimedes engines (1st stage). Distinctive 'Hungry Hippo' reusable fairings. Partially reusable. First launch Q1 2026 or later.
